acne.title: Acne
acne.summary: Acne is common and often linked to clogged pores, oil production, and bacteria. These gentle, evidence-based tips can help manage mild acne.
tips: Cleanse face twice daily with a gentle, non-comedogenic cleanser.
Avoid heavy or occlusive cosmetics; use oil-free products.
Do not pick or squeeze pimples; it increases infection and scarring risk.
Use topical products with salicylic acid or benzoyl peroxide (start low concentration).
Maintain a balanced diet, hydrate, and avoid excessive sugar/greasy snacks.

eczema.title: Eczema (Atopic dermatitis)
eczema.summary: Eczema causes red, itchy patches. Gentle skin care, moisturization, and avoiding triggers often help reduce flare-ups.
tips: Use a fragrance-free, thick moisturizer immediately after bathing to seal moisture.
Take short, lukewarm showers and avoid hot water which dries skin.
Wear soft, breathable fabrics and avoid harsh detergents or fragrances.
Consider an over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream for mild flare-ups and consult a doctor for persistent cases.
Keep nails short and use gentle cleaning for affected areas to avoid rubbing.

rosacea.title: Rosacea-like signs
rosacea.summary: Rosacea causes facial redness and flushing. Gentle care and avoiding triggers can reduce symptoms; medical treatment may be necessary for moderate cases.
tips: Avoid triggers such as hot drinks, spicy foods, alcohol, and strong sunlight.
Use gentle cleansers and broad-spectrum sunscreen daily (SPF 30+).
Avoid abrasive scrubs and products with alcohol or strong fragrances.
Consider seeing a dermatologist for topical or oral therapy if redness persists.
Keep a trigger diary to identify foods/activities causing flare-ups.

normal.summary: Your skin appears within normal range in this scan. Maintain healthy routines to preserve skin health.

Stay hydrated and eat a balanced diet with fruits and vegetables.
Get regular sleep and manage stress to support skin health.
